de.thesycon.usbio
Class UsbIoBufPool

java.lang.Object
  de.thesycon.usbio.UsbIoBufPool
public class UsbIoBufPool
extends java.lang.Object

This class implements a pool of UsbIoBuf objects. It is used by UsbIoReader and UsbIoWriter to simplify management of buffer pools.

Version:
2.0
Author:
Thesycon

Constructor Detail

UsbIoBufPool

public UsbIoBufPool()
Method Detail

allocate

public boolean allocate(int SizeOfBuffer,
                        int NumberOfBuffers)
Allocate all elements of the buffer pool.

The function allocates the required number of buffer descriptors (UsbIoBuf objects). Then it allocates the specified amount of buffer memory. The total number of bytes to allocate is calculated as follows.

The function fails by returning false when an internal pool is already allocated.

Parameters:
SizeOfBuffer - Specifies the size, in bytes, of the buffers to be allocated internally.
NumberOfBuffers - Specifies the number of buffers to be allocated internally.
Returns:
Returns true in case of success, false otherwise.
See Also:
free()

getCurrentCount

public int getCurrentCount()
Get current number of buffers in the pool.

Returns:
The function returns the current number of buffers stored in the pool.
See Also:
get(), put(UsbIoBuf)

get

public UsbIoBuf get()
Get a buffer from the pool.

The function removes a buffer from the pool and returns a reference to the associated descriptor. The caller is responsible for releasing the buffer, see put.

Returns:
The function returns a reference to the buffer descriptor removed from the pool, or null if the pool is exhausted.
See Also:
getCurrentCount(), put(UsbIoBuf)

put

public void put(UsbIoBuf Buf)
Put a buffer back to the pool.

This function is called to release a buffer that was returned by get.

Parameters:
Buf - Reference to the buffer descriptor that was returned by get.
See Also:
getCurrentCount(), get()

free

public void free()
Free all elements of the buffer pool.

The function frees all buffer descriptors and all the buffer memory allocated by a call to allocate. The pool is empty after this call.

A call to Free on an empty pool is allowed. The function does nothing in this case.

Note that after a call to Free, another pool can be allocated by means of allocate.

See Also:
allocate(int, int)
